note.p: Birth: Saint Ambroix, Languedoc, France, Europe (17 September 1615)
Education: Educated by his uncle, Samuel Petit; Paris; MD

Career: Practised in Holland (until 1650); published French translation of Thomas More's 'Utopia' (1643), of Thomas Hobbes' 'De Cive' (1649), and of Hobbes' 'De Corpore Politico, or the Elements of Law' (1652); Director of the College d'Orange; raised as a Protestant, he converted to Catholicism (1653) and became a priest; travelled to Rome (1655 and 1667); Historiographer to Louis XIV (1660); held a number of minor benefices
Other RSActivity: Contributed to observations and experiments (1663)
References: A G A Balz, 'Samuel Sorbière (1615-1670)', in The Philosophical Review, 1930, vol. 39(6), pp.573-586
E Faure-Fremiet, 'Les Origines de l'Academie des Sciences de Paris' in NR 1966 vol 21 pp 20-31
L T Sarasohn, 'Who was then the gentleman?: Samuel Sorbière, Thomas Hobbes, and the Royal Society', in History of Science, 2004, vol.42, pp.211-232

Notes: The election date is Sorbiere's election date into the Society after the grant of the second charter in April 1663. All Fellows admitted in a two-month window after this charter, until 22 June 1663, are considered Original Fellows.
